commentBody:
SlipCOVERS?
SeatCOVERS?
SOFACOVERS!

Otherwise, a quickie.
Now for some NEATVODKA.

Cheers, Tracy.
I thought I had something wrong with QUIPU, even though I‚Äôd seen a tv show that discussed them‚Ä¶ Quick Saturday!

Wow looks like I‚Äôm first. I enjoyed this puzzle, top half seemed easier than the bottom to me. Big fan of the GUTTERBALL clue. Took a while to figure out the VALLEY part of UNCANNYVALLEY, I guess that‚Äôs the dip in the graph of human responses to robots as they get more lifelike (we don‚Äôt notice if they are perfectly lifelike, and don‚Äôt mind if they are not lifelike, but get freaked out if they are almost lifelike). I learned a few things today which in my mind is a great addition to a puzzle.
Two in a row that were too easy for the end of the week.

The comments this time around, I'm sure, are going to center on square 46, where an entry people are going to complain is a foreign word and very obscure crosses with a topic that some people (i.e. those with closed or narrow minds) would not like to see in a crossword. It's really not a Natick, since the Q is inferrable in the across answer, but people are going to say it was a "personal Natick". People are also going to say that they didn't know UNCANNY VALLEY or YANN Tiersen (I did know the former, but not the latter.) They're also going to complain about Brendon (yes, Caitlin, that's how he spells it) URIE, since he was featured here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FuXNumBwDOM While URIE is for the youngs, NENA is for the olds. Or at least the moderately olds. And of course, there's STARKEY, which Caitlin covered in the column.
what if i started using a QUIPU to track my personal finances‚Ä¶ü§î

BUTTERBALL.
And Ira Glass.
That was my uncanny valley for today. 
(I always like a little uncanniness in my puzzle)

"How's the furniture business?"
"Pretty good sofa!"

("At least it's not a wild goose chaise!")

I thought this was a terrific puzzle, even though I had an awful time getting a toehold. I found it quite chewy, with some weirdness sprinkled in, and was surprised when I didn't exceed my average. Congrats Tracy!

I thought it was quite challenging but finished in a reasonable time .
It was only when I'd finished and  was then looking at neatvodka for a little while that I realized what it was lol.
UNCANNY VALLEY is not to be confused with the UNCANDY VALLEY, a summer camp between the hills for sugar-addicted children.

I thought I was breezing through this one. Was well over half done in 10 minutes. My final solve time was over 30 minutes. Alley opps and glass production really tripped me up.

I didn't know QUIPU, so I thought maybe OmERA was the historic name for a glass blower. Took me a while to realize it meant Phillip Glass. It took just as long to realize that alley oops were bowling mistakes, not basketball assists.

I was able to work out QUEER___OLOGY, and I really wanted those three squares to be ETYM, but obviously that wasn't it. Struggled with those crossings too for a while. And I had STARtat for 34A for far too long before I got NEATVODKA
Maybe we need a natick-like term for a cross of two foreign words like OSSO and CHASSE. Other than that, an enjoyable test. That clue for GUTTERBALL is my favorite one in awhile.

Whoosh! Very proud of myself for finishing (I thought) in under 10 minutes despite it being 4:30am. Screeching stop! Not getting the happy music and spending the next 3 whole minutes combing the grid for errors. Finally walking away for a few minutes, summoned to resolve existential angst afflicting the cat just then. (My husband has an uncanny talent for sleeping through all manner of existential angst.) Feline feelings soothed, returning to the grid and‚Äîsheesh, finally!‚Äîbeginning to question my answer to [Alley oop]. 

I guess y‚Äôall don‚Äôt call it bUTTERBALL after all.

I really wanted 41A to be "lucky", as getting Wordle in 1 is ... well, lucky. But YALL disproved that immediately. (Not a quibble against the clue! Just where my brain went first. 

46D for some reason made me think of abaci, though a) the singular form didn't fit and b) abacuses didn't use knots. But QUIPU got dredged up from the corners of memory so I didn't have too much trouble there. 

Had trap before DELT but I was pretty sure 24D was HAND. 

NIFTY puzzle but I had to hunt for a couple of what turned out to be sneaky typos, those UTTER CADS.

I'm risking all the eye rolls to say that porter is a style of, not an alternative to, ale.

That is all.
New Saturday PB. I choose to believe that I am that much smarter than the last time I set a PB vs this puzzle being on the lower end of the challenge scale.
But porters are ALES...

Thank you, Tracy. Loved this chewy puzzle. This GenXer liked seeing both Brendon URIE and NENA in the grid. I think I would choose this Panic! At The Disco song as my theme song if I ever got a puzzle published in the NYT‚Ä¶ https://youtu.be/BzbxacRr5Gk?si=0UmlRE5C_YsSc06s Enjoy!

Not bad. I think the clue for SLUE should have had a (var.) note. But overall, this was solid, and I liked the UNCANNYVALLEY entry, and the clue for GUTTERBALL.

8/10
When does she sleep?

This was a good workout.  The upper middle caused me lots of trouble.  YANN Tiersen was unknown to me and UNCANNYVALLEY did not compute.  For some reason I tried orethieves, instead of ARTTHIEVES, thinking maybe there was some linguist basis for treating oil as an ore.  So I sighed with relief when that section finally revealed itself to me.  Alas there was a typo somewhere that was holding me up, but when I scanned the grid, everything seemed right.  A more rigorous review revealed that I had blob instead of GLOB.  I‚Äôm so conditioned to solve by crosses that I had just accepted butterball as a valid answer for alley oop because it looked reasonable, even if didn‚Äôt know why it made sense (see UNCANNYVALLEY above).  Face palm when I caught my mistake and saw that the alley oop was quite clever.  This one was certainly no slam dunk for me.

This was not what I would exactly call an epic game, but the clues were crafty and the fills were fun, and it was in no way rinkydink. I had to peer at at that uncanny valley of queer theology to be sure I was not getting lost in the sofa covers, but I got the idea and when it was time to stop I realized that I'd had a lovely time and would have liked to spend even more.

Thank you, Tracy, for a classy puzzle.  Your professional expertise shows us how it's done.

Not an easy one for me, but satisfying to solve. Blob vs glob was my downfall.  I was thinking of an alley oop in basketball, but butterball made no sense.  Tried glob then the bowling reference hit me. Kinda clever clue! Although butterball could also relate to bowling as I‚Äôve had a few balls slip off my fingers straight into the gutter. Happy Friday!

Gave me a pretty good battle.

I would have won had I not though things tettered on the brink rather than teeters on the brink.

Oh well, NEATVODKA was a struggle that I did win, and I loved TONGUETIE and GUTTERBALL.
Very tricky but I got it with no lookups after 2 hours and four minutes. Truly Saturday difficult.

UNCANNY VALLEY is incorrectly clued. It‚Äôs not a term used to describe robots that seem ‚Äútoo lifelike‚Äù ‚Äî if it were, after all, we perfectly lifelike humans would all reside there, not just robots.

Robotics professor Masahiro Mori coined the term to describe the valley-shaped section of a graph charting our emotional response to robots as they become more lifelike ‚Äî a steep dip into near-revulsion followed by steep improvement as their appearance becomes lifelike enough to the same empathy we feel toward other humans.

The robot designs in the uncanny valley are not ‚Äútoo human‚Äù; they are exactly not human enough.
Yann Tiersen's contributions on the Am√©lie soundtrack are a joy!

Favorite clue:  8D:  it's a Straight Shot.   I was sitting there with KA at the end, preceded by a possible D for cads.   And I was thinking to myself, nothing the on dka.   When I finally solved it I grinned.   Nicely done Tracy!

A Saturday I somehow solved without lookups. Always happy to get one of those.

But can someone please help me out with a clue that despite my  Saturday success I‚Äôm apparently too thick-skulled to grok?

‚ÄúCould be certain?‚Äù ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Thanks in advance for assisting me in what I expect to be another in a long, personal history of forehead slapping moments.
I really liked this puzzle. Of course I'm starting to like every one that doesn't have 5 letters to a square (or start moving when I finish it).

It felt like a good Saturday puzzle, but for me it was too difficult to finish without several lookups and autocheck. As a foreign solver, I face some frustrating challenges. Take the string and knot record-keeping device. I learned the name as a pre-teen. I was fascinated by the Inca. I studied them for a long time, inspired by the very sad story of the fall of their empire and destruction of their culture at the hands of the cruel, avaricious and bigoted Spaniards ("Let's torture, rob and klil these people for Jesus!"). I learned about their gods, their cities, their culture, and, yes, about their record keeping. What's the problem then? Shouldn't QUIPU have been a gimme? It was, but... I've known it for decades as kipu, because that's how we spell it in Polish (it sounds the same as your version, which I was unfamiliar with). So my gimme really wasn't a gimme. The discovery of a kipu (well, quipu...) at the castle of Niedzica in Southern Poland in 1946 is one of our historical mysteries. You can read about it in the Legend section of the Wikipedia article on the castle: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niedzica_Castle

Was surprised to solve this in under 11 minutes (even after a decent stumble with YESAND) but it can‚Äôt hurt that I‚Äôve been on a Manny Nosowsky kick in the archives lately‚Ä¶my goodness, there are some workouts in there!
Nice Saturday puzzle, about 10% under my average. My only nit is, 23D. It reminds me of Moss in The IT Crowd. https://youtu.be/NdREEcfaihg?si=Nl3Lx3mcPNcsMhJ3 [Porter _is_ ale!]
I‚Äôm pretty sure a PETSCAN is 2D, not 3D, ie it produces a single flat image.

Although I managed to solve (without lookups) in a fair bit less time than my Saturday average, I was unfamiliar with both seed entries. UNCANNY VALLEY sounded weird, although I had heard of the concept; and while QUEER? was obvious for 46A, it took the crosses for me to get the _THEOLOGY. It is not especially unusual for me to draw a blank on some names‚Äîyesterday‚Äôs baseballer, for example, was one‚Äîbut I can‚Äôt recall ever being so confuzzled by key phrases. It is, however, always good to learn something new! Enjoyed this one!
Please bring back Saturday level cluing!

I enjoyed this one. 
SLUE I spell slew, and know nothing about improv and UNCANNY VALLEY!? What an amazing concept. 

Despite not knowing CAREY, PERE or any EPIC GAMES, or CADET BLUE (or Kelly green), URIE or YANN, I found the crossers extremely helpful there. I only revealed URIE - couldn‚Äôt guess. 

I was sure it was glitterball, and it took a few seconds of thought to work out the meaning of gutter. My attempt at bowling led to every single ball going into the gutter. I was better at hockey, on a field, not ice. 

Yes, nice one.
You had me at RINKYDINK, Tracy!  Thanks for a thoroughly enjoyable puzzle.

I can't believe I finished this puzzle without any lookups, and in one sitting at that. So much of the fill wasn't in my wheelhouse. In fact, one of the few gimmees was what I consider to be a bit of arcana,  and that is QUIPU. One of the benefits of majoring in Spanish, I guess. Maybe it's well-known, but somehow I doubt it.

Despite the fact that it took me much less time then I thought at first pass, I didn't really enjoy it. Too many unknowns that I had to get from the crosses, such as UNCANNY VALLEY and QUEER THEOLOGY.
Thanks Tracy. Nice seeing your name here. 34A excellent.
Not that anyone cares, but for anyone (like me, initially) who says, "But Nena was the name of the band!"--this is true, but it was also the stage name of the lead singer, so the clue is correct.

One of my favorite constructors. Typical tough Saturday for me and had to look up some things, but ended up being an enjoyable workout as things finally dawned on me from the crosses. *One puzzle find today was inspired by 36 down. Dawned on me that... YALLCOMEBACKNOW is 15 letters, and... yep - it was in one puzzle. A Monday from February 4, 2008 by Dave and Tracey Mackey. The two other theme answers in that one were: DONTBEASTRANGER (also 15 letters) and DROPINANYTIME Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/4/2008&g=59&d=A I'll put my other puzzle find in a reply. ...

No, that wasn't too easy.

But clever and fun -- especially alley oops.

A capital-P Puzzle, riddles galore.  Seven no-knows.  Plenty of wait-fors (clues yielding several answers).   Even [Fencing option] ‚Äì are we talking the sword sport or area enclosure?

I love things like this that set me behind in filling out a grid, hills to conquer.  What results are oho‚Äôs and aha‚Äôs and TILs, those Crosslandia carrots that keep me coming back.  And the sweet feeling at fill-in that it was well-earned.

The stars of the box today are the horizontal triple stacks in the NE and SW.  First, they are remarkably fresh ‚Äì all NYT debuts in the NE, and in the SW, two debuts and one once-before.  Second, they are so varied!  Can you get more disparate than SOFA COVERS, ART THIEVES, and UNCANNY VALLEY?  Or QUEER THEOLOGY, GUTTERBALL, and LITERALIST?  Mwah!

I liked UTTER crossing UTTER in the SW.  I loved what happened when I saw HAIRY abutting ELSIE ‚Äì my brain shouted ‚ÄúWhen Hairy met Elsie!‚Äù. (Hello, Meg Ryan fans!)

Needless to say, Tracy, I relished your first-class creation.  Thank you so much for this!
"Tierra"?? Paging Dr. Tyson!

Oh, Tracy, don't tease me with hamantash then throw me an ONION ROLL!

Otherwise, it was an enjoyable solve.

TIL about UNCANNY VALLEY.

For those who haven't looked it up the VALLEY in question refers to  a dip in a graph, on which "human likeness" is plotted against "affinity".  It's been hypothesized that as an object become more "human-like" us humans will have a greater affinity to it, but at a certain point we become freaked out and affinity drops sharply...only to shoot back up when the object becomes extremely life-like.

Though originally hypothesized and named in 1970 (according to Wikipedia), it still maintains its status as a hypothesis.  Proof is hard to come by!
Really enjoyed this one!
One could argue that getting a wordle in one isn‚Äôt ACING but lucking out, as there‚Äôs absolutely no skill involved in that.

Nothin‚Äô RINKYDINK about this one.

Did *not* know (as in, never, ever heard of)
a few, which is fabulous.

Cause, now I do.
Thank you Tracy!

But, üôã‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è I have a question.
[ Keeps greasing the squeaky wheel? ]
Is that a double-misdirect?
A triple, even?

This comes up quite often in late-week puzzles.
The question mark, the answer‚Ä¶

If I‚Äôm already reading every clue 
from a twisty angle, 
the straight-forwardness throws me!

Sometimes I have to struggle to
read clues in the ‚Äúobvious‚Äù way, 
because it‚Äôs a late-week and 
I‚Äôm so suspicious.

Like watching a whodunnit.
Every single character seems shady.

So, when it turns out it really *was* the creepy butler‚Ä¶
Wha..?

When I realized it was REOILS, my head just spun around.

Cannot possibly just be me. 
Right..?
Got it, but‚Ä¶
Awful crossword today. Who wrote these clues?

Another short streak comes to its inevitable end.

Initially decided that "one of the pillars of improv" was BE SAND, since sand flows so nicely, as in an hourglass. That the French musician was then named BANN was not sufficiently concerning to save me.

As soon as I didn't get the music, I remembered YES AND from a fairly recent puzzle. But, alas, I don't allow myself errors or lookups, so my streak was kaput.

Have absolutely for certain never ever heard/seen/encountered UNCANNYVALLEY. Even the clue confounds me, since a "valley" is not a "phenomenon". Obviously I'm missing everything about this entry, which I got largely from the crosses. 

A fine construction, except for G(UTTER)BALL crossing UTTER. That noted, the clue for GUTTERBALL was so clever that my nit is withdrawn.

‚ÄúCertain oRE‚Äù is a thing, and ConS made sense, and I had no idea who YAN- Tiersen was, so it took a while to figure out what the straight shot was. 

A pleasant early Saturday.
Former AP World History teacher here: thrilled to see "quipu" in the crossword.  I knew it immediately, but I suspect that was a tough one for most folks.
This was a very educational puzzle! Not to give it away I never had heard its first word ! Nor many  of its esoteric phrases.
Am I the only dummy who thought it was QUIlt? And does anybody know if this is the same Gary Larson who does the Far Side comics.
I never kneu.

First I had DUNKERBALL and DROP, then BUTTERBALL and BLOB (I was struggling to relate basketball to Turkey), but I finally got there with a groan (and perhaps a TSK). I think a ? would have been helpful for this clue. I also had ADVIL for far too long. Fun puzzle. I particularly enjoyed RINKYDINK! After this I‚Äôll need an ONIONROLL and a cup of coffee to revive me.

So weird‚Ä¶ a can of corn got jammed in that valley between the cushions of my sofa. Seems almost impossible‚Ä¶

What a great Saturday puzzle: intelligent and human(e).

I always learn new facts when I do The NY Times CW. Didn't know about the Quipu, Uncanny Valley, or Queer Theology. A week or so ago, I learned about Pistol Pete and watched videos of his incredible basketball technique, listened to interviews of players I know talking about him. The puzzle is a window into unexplored parts of the world. I love it!
This was a tough one. So many new words to me. Great for a Saturday. Now let‚Äôs see if I can remember any of these new things. Thanks!

Wonderful.  Bravo !  

I particularly enjoyed the cluing after I finally deciphered them with great effort.
Just the right amount of difficult! Very clever clueing.

Since it seems no one has expressed any curiosity about today's clue for EDIE, here's an interesting (and perhaps still unresolved) story from 2016: https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-wales-south-east-wales-36028459 Was Nina's prize returned to her descendants?
Thinking of the Turing Test, I had UNCANNYVOLLEY
Oh no, I walked away for a while and had a finish time of five and a half hours! Boy! That will screw up my average times. I closed the tab, don't know what happened.

This one was tough, but I was determined to hack my way through with no help at all. While my time was just shy of 20 minutes above my average, I am satisfied since I did manage to avoid looking anything up. Loved so many of the clues, even those that had me flummoxed, especially ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a straight shot,‚Äù for NEAT  VODKA. So many new words/phrases today, which also makes me happy since there‚Äôs so much to lookup: QUIPU; UNCANNY VALLEY. I‚Äôd never heard of YANN Tiersen until today but I‚Äôm listening to, and enjoying, his Liquid Hour as I write this.

A million thanks to Tracy Bennett for such a wonderful start to my Saturday.

That was a very tough Saturday for me, but in a good way. So many unknowns, plus a few ‚ÄòI know it but can‚Äôt recall it‚Äô ones. UNCANNY VALLEY was one. I got the first bit, but needed all the crosses to reveal the dip. Cue head slap. 
A fair few misdirects too; clot/blot/glop. Lord before LADY, Advil before ALEVE, though I‚Äôm quite proud that I know two medicines that don‚Äôt exist in the UK.

Despite my struggle with the puzzle and needing a fair number of look ups, I think this is a perfect Saturday grid, a real brain stretcher.

Sigh. We‚Äôre supposed to get rain today. Nothing but slightly damp air is what arrived. The land is rapidly turning into a dust bowl. This is supposed to be the wet, green Island, where it always rains. What‚Äôs happened? *insert opinion on climate change here*
Same as others said, very tough but fun to fail at.
That was tough, but I did it!  Love it when I get the gold star on my last letter fill and don‚Äôt have to go searching for my mistake(s).
No matter what I do, my comment won't pass the gatekeeper....

Today's score:  Bennett 2, Carson 1.  Struck out on Wordle (was down to 2 possible words and chose incorrectly) and had to look up the French composer (but knew the American!).   Fortunately Strands soothed some of the bruised ego.  

Well done and thanks.

Seems like mixed opinions on difficulty today. For me it was quite ‚ÄúdiceY‚Äù - which is what I had for 48 down for quite a while (with QUEER idEOLOGY for 46 across - which seemed much more likely than ‚Äúqueer theology‚Äù which I hadn‚Äôt heard of).

Finally figuring out the meaning of ‚Äúalley oops‚Äù (great clue) helped me resolve that area. I also had a lot of trouble with the NW, keeping caTSCAN for far too long. I‚Äôve heard of a PET scan but had no idea what it actually was (until looking it up after finishing the puzzle). Pretty funny that they both kinda sound like medical imaging for your animal companion ü§ì. I know that a CAT scan is now more commonly called a CT scan.
I started out despairing, even knowing UNCANNY VALLEY.  But ONION ROLL and ART THIEVES brought me back.

This puzzzle certainly introduced me to a stack of new IDEAS and vocab terms.
Tracy the Tricky was in full flight!

For 10D Blanket, I had COVER UP (off the P from Father Marquette) so that was a mess.
I knew the Italian for Bone and the Boston paper, but since I had a year of TYPING instruction in 10th grade (it was very thorough) I knew the asterisk meant SEE NOTE.  No one, especially not the teacher, called it a STAR KEY.  I still don't.

And the book titles!  Did they sound like B  ROMANCE novels to you, too?  
My final act was to change the B in BLOB to G in order to make sense of "Alley oopS"...(?Alley Oop was a BUTTERBALL?  I just thought he was strong!)
Apparently I spent most of the puzzle in UNCANNY VALLEY...(Where? What?)

ART THIEVES is a fine tip of the hat 
to 2024's Sunday Puzzle of the Year.

STARKEY is still the Beatles drummer‚Äôs legal surname. ‚ÄúRingo Starr‚Äù has only ever been a stage name.

UNCANNY VALLEY does not refer to faces looking ‚Äútoo lifelike.‚Äù It‚Äôs when they look almost lifelike and our lizard brain associates that with a corpse.

Between the clues and the answers this puzzle had more than its share of dumb stuff. Not a very good Saturday puzzle.

OK. OK. Look as a gay seminary graduate, I'm going to like any puzzle that includes QUEER THEOLOGY. But this puzzle, Friday's, and Thursday's I simply burned through. Either I have just been on the same mental wavelength as the last three puzzle constructors, or the NYT crosswords simply have not been challenging enough this week. Frankly, I'm not that good. I struggled more with the LA Times this week. C'mon, Will, up your game. (Famous last words when the Sunday puzzle leaves me in tears...)

I started this puzzle at 10pm, on the floor in the hallway, sitting next to my trembling dog. 
I continued this puzzle at 1am, outside a closet, promising my dog that this terror would eventually end.
I fell asleep at 3 am, to a continued barrage of pops and crackles.
I finished this puzzle at 9am, while my dog finally got some rest.

I hate fireworks season. I liked this puzzle.

When I read the clue for three down, bialy, bagel, challah, and knish came rushing into the doors of my awareness all at once, jamming the doorframe and making a ruckus. But no "onion roll" in sight. I had to get most of that from the crosses.

Still don't know what those are...maybe another name for a bialy?

"Uncanny valley"? What about 'SoleyJustabot'? Had never heard of the quipu but what a wonderful invention which reminded me of macrame and then made me think of Madame Defarge and her evil knitting record keeping... and then...!  Had also never referred to the asterisk key on a typewriter as anything other than an asterisk. Fun Saturday crossword. Thanks!

some iffy spots for me. I'll nitpick STAR KEY, EGGY, and BLOCKY.

But I liked QUEER THEOLOGY and RINKY DINK!

100 days for me!

I mean, I know the streak isn‚Äôt the most important thing, but‚Ä¶ Does anyone else have the issue when you put in the final letter, the screen pops up to say you‚Äôre done! Gold star! But then it glitches and loads super slow - then when you go back to the main Games page, it shows that you haven‚Äôt finished the puzzle? But when you go back to the puzzle it IS finished and can‚Äôt ‚ÄúResume‚Äù because it‚Äôs done! (This is when solving on my iPhone) Only way is to reload and redo, which then gives the blue star instead of the gold üò§ 

Probably the third time it‚Äôs done this in the past couple of months. I know - first world problems but considering the Times is supposed to be a first class crossword, it‚Äôs just irritating enough to give a slight blue tinge to my morning.

So the real question - is it just me? ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüòÅ

Did TONGUETIE remind anyone else of Twin Peaks? -- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JLiGZ0a8pHM Great puzzle with some utterly fresh entries and two new-to-me animal varieties, the COOLANT and the PEERAT. I now present to you UNCANNY VALLEY by Johnny Flynn(co-written by Robert Macfarlane): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pgXHqhkNMOw (If you're not familiar with Johnny Flynn, that's on you.)

How UNCANNY that I had just read the recent Atlantic article about the QUIPU: https://www.theatlantic.com/culture/archive/2025/05/decoding-ancient-incas-writing-system-khipus/682814/?gift=9PmITfHok9x1rLOJaHU0G5mmQoRQKaHLqrOG9R0ZYhM&utm_source=copy-link&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=share

If they gave you 5000 guesses -- and you had UNCANNY something-or-other --
would you ever guess VALLEY as the 2nd word?  Me neither.  This is certainly one of the oddest phrases ever invented.  I can understand something like UNCANNY HUMANITY or UNCANNY REALITY.  How about SPOOKY DETOO?  UNCANNY VALLEY is so anti-intuitive that I'm predicting it won't have staying power.  Unless, of course, it's been around forever -- and it's already proved it has.

Back to the rest of the puzzle.  It's a NIFTY Saturday, lively and well-clued.  Colorful fill like TONGUE TIED  and RINKY-DINK.  Nice clues for CADET BLUE;  CHASSE and GUTTER BALL.  Liked how HISS and TSKS were clued the same way.  Not too many names.  QUIPU, which I'll remember for less than 5 minutes, was fairly crossed.  Hard in places, easy in others, and very enjoyable.
idk if it was just my knowledge gaps or tricky construction but this felt like solving 4 smaller crosswords in one grid! excellent puzzle.
Porters are a type of ale, so 23D essentially says that ales aren‚Äôt as sweet as ales. Otherwise, fairly straightforward clueing (for a Saturday).
Is it just me or did "oil" break a crossword rule?  Left the down blank until the end because I couldn't believe it could be right.  Loved alley oop and straight shot.
NEAT VODKA was a super satisfying late solve.  Can anyone explain ARE for 28D, though? Not getting it‚Ä¶

Loved this puzzle. Don't have time to read the other comments right now, so I hope I'm not repeating others too much. Getting ready to go into NYC to see Hadestown. We've been listening to the cast recording for a couple of weeks and really getting excited. Here's a snippet from the "Glass production," "Akhenaten" that my sister and I saw broadcast live to movie theaters a few years, featuring the incredible counter tenor Anthony Roth Costanzo. https://youtu.be/JG33g_ELdeM?si=-DhlZ9W5hRB63TQG I'm surprised UNCANNY VALLEY is a debut. That was my initial foothold for this puzzle. I loved the misdirecting clues for GUTTER BALL, ART THIEVES, and LITERALIST (although that last one I don't really want to think about) Have a great weekend!
A porter is a type of ale making the use of ALES frustrating. IPAS would have worked for that clue!
50 across is what crosswords are all about. Brilliant.

Southwest corner was one of those ‚ÄúI know I have something wrong, but hell if I know what it is‚Äù corners.  Worked through CLOT (for a long time) and BLOB for 50D, QUEER IDEOLOGY for 46A and therefore DICEY for 48D, BLAST for 58A, PEEP AT for 44D, and ELISE for 49D. I find it interesting that you took such an interest in the existing civilizations that the European invasion overthrew.

Somehow I can't generate much interest, and I wonder if the reason I can't is that I find studying those lands I now occupy very viscerally disturbing.  Why?  I dunno.  It's like the previous residents of a place you are living.  Do I really want to know why they're gone? 

The right would mock my "guilt".  The left might fault me for lack of interests in their cultures.  I feel a little alone on the topic.

Anyway, I'm impressed with your interest in the topic.

@Andrzej

That's really nice.

In science there's this thing called the Citation Index.  This is a compendium of all the times a given paper has been referenced by another paper.

I always thought that was a terrific indicator of what publications succeeded and which didn't (although I nowhere near have a Citation Index "classic" number of references).

So your reading about those gone past seems like a kind of citation index, and little bit of them still alive.

Plus, a lot of the paintings and artifacts of the early aboriginal American depictions had a lot of hotties, too, right?

@Sonja A definition of acing is getting something in one try, as in tennis or golf. Ace is the root. Ace=one, as in playing cards. The clue was correct.

@Tex
I‚Äôve always thought that ‚Äòace‚Äô referred to tennis.
@Jane Wheelaghan it‚Äôs also used in other sports, including volleyball (same sense as tennis, meaning an unreturnable serve) and golf (for a hole in one, I believe).

@CrispyShot 
fun fact (from a vb scout), a tennis ace actually slightly differs from a volleyball one. In tennis, an ace is a serve not touched by the receiving player. If they hit it but not successfully, it is written off as a serve winner. 
In volleyball, an ace is any serve that‚Äôs not successfully returned, regardless of if and how many touches the receiving team makes.

Not that anyone really asked or is claiming otherwise, I just find it curious.



@Tex
I haven‚Äôt seen that definition before, nor it being compared to cards. Merriam-Webster defines the verb as:
a: to earn a high grade on (something, such as an examination) especially: to get an A on
b: to perform extremely well in

Sonja,

Re: volleyball ace

One player on the receiving team can touch the serve and it can still be an ace, but if the first player successfully passes it to a second (or a third) before it is not returned, that's hardly an "ace" for the server.

@Xword Junkie Don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a translation issue as the ‚Äúvalley‚Äù is easy to visualize‚Äîit is created when initial positive feelings toward something that is technologically created to be humanoid dip well into the negative the closer that thing looks to an actual human, and then those feelings return to the positive as the thing trends toward the definitively non-human. So, if you have on an X axis C-3PO from Star Wars (definitely humanoid but not mistakable for human, therefore acceptable and even pleasant to have around), then the robot in the photo accompanying the column (could be mistaken for human at first glance and therefore unsettling and offputting), then Wall-E (100% not humanoid but with just enough anthropomorphism to be adorable and evoke sympathetic responses) you can easily visualize the dip from positive to negative feelings and back up to positive on the Y axis.

@Steve L

I can't imagine *anyone* alive today is familiar with this book, or that it was ever widely read.  I entered EDIE immediately, simply by scanning the word "disobedience".

But, not caring about solve times, I then spent a few minutes wondering if there were some reason that EDIE was hidden in "disobedience", rather than some other long word. Tried to connect the clue to the various other EDIEs who often appear in our puzzles.

I don't think the constructor or editor who wrote the clue had any idea about the book. Simply a coincidence that there happened to be an obscure book from 1899 with the title "Edie's Disobedience".  

But one of the things I enjoy about solving these puzzles are the strange places they lead me. Like to a BBC story about a search for the descendants of a Welsh girl who won a book called "Edie's Disobedience" as a Sunday School prize in 1904.

I prefer to believe there are always reasons to give things second thoughts. ;-)

LORI,

Having [Oil...] in the 21A clue and REOILS as the 9D answer does not break a crossword rule (or convention).

(Was that the right oil?)

@LORI as Barry says below, that crossing technically doesn't break any broad crossword rules/conventions. duplicating words between the answer and its clue is a no-no, but duplicating words in one answer and a different clue is subject to the editor's opinion (some publications care more than others - NYT clearly is not bothered by this!).

@Fritz I had CAT SCAN at first, as i'm sure many others did - but upon reflection, surely a CAT SCAN is a subtype of PET SCAN?

@Tali no, a CAT (or these days usually called CT though same thing) scan uses xrays to create 3-D images. They are for structural exams. PET scans aren't xray based. They involve giving pts a dose of radioactive tracer which is picked up by a scanner and are used to look at functioning, not structure. But there is a combination test, a PET/CT which combines the positron emissions of PET with the xray tech of CT!
